Project Description The proposed Project is designed to reduce poverty by increasing the
incomes of about 425,000 people or 85,000 families. Of these, about
370,000 people, or 74,000 poor families, are expected to move above
the poverty line in 11 districts in six provinces of Indonesia: Central
Kalimantan,  East  Kalimantan,  South  Kalimantan,  Central  Sulawesi,
North Sulawesi, and Southeast Sulawesi. Community-based savings
and loan organizations (CBSLOs) will be formed and trained to support
microenterprises and small enterprises, and needed rural infrastructure
will  be  provided  to  promote  rural  urban  linkages.  The  Project  will
revitalize poverty reduction efforts in the rural sector by supporting the
Government’s  program  to  devolve  development  resources  to  local
governments and strengthening the institutional and human resource
capacity necessary to enable rural communities nationwide to plan and
manage local development initiatives. About 40 more districts from 20
new provinces will benefit from the institutional and capacity-building
program to support the Government decentralization efforts.

Rationale Government’s  successful  poverty  reduction  program  suffered  a
significant set back due to the recent economic crisis. Although the
incidence of poverty has since returned to its pre-crisis level of 18.2
percent, the crisis demonstrated that economic shocks could cause high
surges in the incidence of poverty. It also highlighted the need for a
long-term strategy based on social inclusion and addressing capability
deprivation of the poor to make a significant impact on poverty. Lack of
formal  financial  services  and  institutional  support  from  districts  and
urban business communities are particularly common impediments to
increasing rural enterprise development. The Project aims to remove
these constraints. Past experience indicates that decentralized decision
making  and  devolving  resources  directly  to  local  government
significantly  decreases  the  cost  of  development  implementation  and
increases  the  direct  benefits  of  development  projects  for  local
communities. From that perspective, the Project is intended to support
the  Government’s  renewed  efforts  since  April  1999  to  decentralize
decision  making  and  devolve  development  resources  to  local
governments and communities. Two new laws that were passed in 1999
grant autonomy to district and village governments, in effect giving them
their  own  resources  with  which  to  plan  and  manage  their  own
development  based  on  local  needs.  Such  decision-making  powers
underscore the need for adequate institutional capacity to effect the
democratic  processes  of  decision  making  now  entrusted  to  local
governments and communities. Under this framework, the Project is
aimed at supporting formal and informal training and decision-making
processes  that  would  give  local  communities  and  government  the

III.  BACKGROUND
A.  Sector Description
1.  Poverty in the Rural Sector
3. Prior  to  the  economic  crisis  in  mid-1997,  Indonesia  had  a  sound  record  of  rapid
economic growth, steadily rising development indicators, and an impressive reduction in the
incidence of poverty. Official figures show that poverty declined steadily over a 20-year period,
from 40 percent in 1976 to 11.3 percent in February 1996.5  The record is impressive, but
because of its large population base, in absolute terms, Indonesia has the largest number of
poor people among the countries of Association of Southeast Asian Nations. Two thirds of the
Indonesian poor are rural residents.

4. As a result of the economic crisis since the latter half of 1997, spiraling inflation and
losses of employment opportunities plunged a large proportion of the population into transient
poverty. The incidence of poverty peaked in December 1998 at 24.2 percent6 (21.9 percent
urban and 25.7 percent rural). However, starting in March 1999, Indonesia entered a period of
price deflation, particularly in the price of rice. This, combined with the slow rise in nominal
wages, reversed the trend and the incidence of poverty began to abate. By August 1999, the
latest available official measurement of poverty indicated that poverty had returned to near pre-
crisis levels of 18.2 percent (15.1 percent urban and 20.2 percent rural). The crisis amply
demonstrated that economic shocks can cause dramatically high surges in the incidence of
poverty costly to political and social stability, and long-term development. To make a significant
impact  on  rural  poverty,  combating  poverty  in  Indonesia  must  therefore  involve  prioritizing
development goals – developing a well thought-out and long-term strategy based on social
inclusion – and addressing capability deprivation among the poor.
5. Growth in the rural economy has contributed significantly to Indonesia’s stable economic
growth and in the decline of poverty over the past two decades. Growth in the rural sector
increased the demand for labor and resulted in greater employment and higher real wages in
the economy. A recent study of the real wage data for Indonesia demonstrates that in the
1990s,  poverty  declines  were  inversely  related  to  real  wage  increases.7    Between  1990
and1993, when real agricultural wages in Java increased by 19.2 percent, the number of poor
people declined by 4.8 percent. The relationship was even stronger during 1993-1996 when real
wages increased by 14.2 percent and poverty declined by 13.1 percent. Conversely, as real
wages declined sharply during the economic crisis, poverty incidence increased equally sharply.
Mirroring  the  poverty  trends,  underemployment  (working  less  than  35  hours  a  week)  has
remained a truly rural phenomenon. A recent study by the International Labour Organization
found that, while underemployment affected nearly 60 percent of employed farm workers, only
25 percent of nonagricultural workers were underemployed in 1998.8 Furthermore, a larger
proportion of underemployed rural workers were actively seeking work compared with their
urban counterparts. Improvements in real wages and rapid creation of jobs for unskilled and
semi-skilled workers are thus key to a long-term strategy for poverty reduction.
6. The  economic  crisis  significantly  aggravated  the  poverty  situation,  but  the  political
turmoil that followed showed the weakness of focusing on income alone and not addressing
also the issues of social exclusion,9 which left the country susceptible to political unrest. The
concept of social exclusion provides a good framework for discussing the factors affecting the
capability deprivation of the rural poor. The rural poor have been excluded from many activities
that  could  otherwise  allow  them  to  improve  their  income  and  quality  of  life.  The  political
processes in rural communities have largely been driven by appointed officials. Decisions on
development priorities emanating from central ministries not only exclude the poor from the
process  of  setting  development  priorities,  but  also  provide  no  accountability  check  on  the
performance of the responsible authorities. Given the remoteness of many rural areas, the poor
can be physically excluded from markets, financial services, and social services (like health care
and education) because the transaction cost to gain access to these markets or services is
beyond their means. The rural poor are also excluded from a broad body of information ranging

7. A widely held belief is that the centralized and top-down approaches that characterize
development planning and investments in Indonesia have not been cost-efficient; they have
socially excluded the community, particularly the poor, and have had the unintended effect of
creating large pockets of underserviced areas. Overly centralized planning structures tend to
favor over-generalized selection criteria so that local demands and needs of socially vulnerable
groups are often overlooked. As a result of exclusion, many poverty-reduction programs are not
designed with sufficient sensitivity to the poor so that services often miss their intended targets.
Many programs are unsustainable for lack of local demand and ownership. In an effort to make
the system inclusive, bottom-up planning was introduced in Indonesia in 1981: village proposals
were formulated by village committees representing each sector. However, studies show that
only 5-10 percent of the proposals generated at the village level and forwarded to higher levels
were funded. The reasons given for this lack of success included the lack of human resources
to conduct the participatory processes adequately, lack of local planning skills, and dominance
of district sectoral agencies in decision making.
8. Poor rural communities were cut off from economic growth in the past. They are, as
noted above, physically excluded or inadequately linked to the transportation and marketing
networks that serve growth centers. Hence, lack of adequate rural infrastructure is a good proxy
for  the  many  related  constraints  faced  by  such  communities,  including  the  lack  of  social
services. Experience shows that communities can be relied upon to identify crucial linkages to
markets, and are capable of planning and implementing the construction of small scale rural
infrastructure. Leaving the decision-making powers with communities, which can also have a
substantial role in constructing infrastructure, fosters community ownership and transparency in
implementing  project  activities.  Similar  insights  were  drawn  from  experience  elsewhere  in
Asia—lack of rural infrastructure underlies the disadvantaged economic position of the rural
poor.10 In a recent World Bank survey of poverty in Indonesia, the poor unanimously cited lack
of income generation opportunities as an underlying cause of their disadvantaged economic
position.11 In short, groups that are physically excluded from the mainstream economy are
deprived of the opportunity to expand their capabilities and remain trapped in a cycle of poverty.
2. Financial Institutions
9. The communities in the rural areas targeted by the Project show a wide range of
capabilities  to  produce  goods  and  services.  However,  lack  of  credit  and  lack  of  social
preparation  suppress  the  entrepreneurial  initiatives  of  the  poor.  The  vast  majority  of
communities, especially their poorer members, have no access to formal financial services.
Even schemes such as those operated by Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BRI) through its village unit
network do not reach most villages and tend to cater to those with incomes well above the
poverty line. It may also be noted that where BRI operates in the rural areas of Kalimantan and
Sulawesi, it has a complete or near monopoly which, naturally, it is reluctant to share. Another
successful approach to finance is the privately based credit unions (para. 13), but these are not
yet active in the project area. Although there are savings groups (arisan) in the project area,
almost always they are organized by women, whose members by choice are limited to 25 to 30.
The money from such a savings group is not enough to meet the business capital needs of all
members or the needs for their children’s education. As a result, a larger group – community-

10. At present, the services of commercial banks are not available in the project area.
Nevertheless, six regional development banks (BPDs), have expressed interest in participating

Potentially, they could develop into very useful alternative financial institutions as wholesalers of
credit to small organizations such as CBSLOs in the project area. The BPDs recognize that
taking  part  in  a  project  of  this  nature  is  challenging,  and  could  lead  to  a  much  stronger
contribution to the development of financial services and an improvement in their skills in
lending on a commercial risk-bearing basis. The BPDs have solid financial expertise; however,
they will need training in risk assessment in relation to small organizations engaged in savings
and lending, such as the envisaged CBSLOs. As part of this training, the BPDs will be exposed
to existing, successful primary credit unions or similar organizations to experience at firsthand
the process of initial formation and first stage development, the membership rules that have to
be established, and possible legal structures. From this process, they will develop the skills not
only for taking part in the project but also for continuing such activities after project completion.
11. It is noted that the six BPDs have limited experience in providing wholesale credit to
nonbank organizations whose members are the ultimate borrowers. These funds were obtained
from  Bank  Indonesia.  One  BPD,  BPD  South  Kalimantan,  has  had  broader  and  longer
experience in wholesaling credit, being a participant in the ADB Microcredit Project13 since the
start of the Project in 1994. Although the BPDs have their main headquarters in the provincial
capitals, they have a branch or subbranch in almost all of the project districts.
12. Many NGOs have been effective in facilitating social preparation of communities and

implementation.

existing  organizations  or  by  members  of  such  organizations  can  help  enormously.  The
introduction and training process are best conducted by those who have direct experience
elsewhere, especially NGOs or others independent of government. Indonesia has had a strong
cooperative movement for about 30 years. The Credit Union Federation is the national-level
organization of the Indonesian credit union movement. It has 27 regional chapters nationwide,
including three regional credit unions in the project area: one each in North Sulawesi, South
Sulawesi, and Central Sulawesi. They comprise 53 local credit unions with a total savings of
Rp4,852  million  ($585,000  equivalent).  Although  there  are  no  credit  unions  in  the  three
Kalimantan provinces, there is one regional chapter in West Kalimantan, which has 27 local
credit unions with savings of Rp14,288 million ($517,000 equivalent).
14. The basic rules and principles that a savings and loan organization (such as the CBSLO)
need to incorporate into its founding documentation can easily be drawn from the Credit Union
Federation with wide experience in the field, but the members themselves should have the final
say. The same applies to procedures for making and recording savings, and later loans, as the
organization  develops.  The  level  of  deposits,  membership,  and  activity  required  before
drawdown can be made by CBSLO will be subject to project guidelines, but will also depend on
the agreement reached with the BPD itself.
3. Women in Development
15. Women in the rural areas of the Project contribute to economic development in many
ways.  They  are  involved  in  agricultural  work,  participating  in  production  and  postharvest
activities. To augment farm income, women conduct petty trading by selling snacks and meals
they prepare at home, and selling vegetables and fruits from their gardens. Many are also
involved in cottage industries such as making rattan mats and finishing local semiprecious
stones.  They  also  seek  employment  as  farm  workers  or  daily  work  as  laborers  in  local
construction projects. However, women in the project area suffer from low wages and lack of
access  to  capital,  skills  training,  appropriate  technology,  extension  services,  and  market
facilities. Due to lack of access to formal credit, women depend on private moneylenders and
borrow funds at exorbitant interest rates. As noted, the resources of the small arisan savings
group are not sufficient to meet all of its members needs; however, the social capital that has
been developed in forming these groups can be tapped in forming CBSLOs.

17. Laws 22 and 25 which were passed in 1999, hold the promise of a decentralized

autonomous areas to elect through democratic processes representatives for village councils,
replacing the previously government-appointed village heads and committees. These changes
are expected to spawn local government-sponsored development initiatives more attuned to
local community needs. Viewed in the context of social exclusion, the two laws constitute a
critically important initiative. They give communities, including the poor within the communities,
the power to hold local leaders accountable.
18. The Government’s development priorities are contained in its medium-term development

structural  poverty  programs.  PROPENAS  also  addresses  a  range  of  cross-cutting  issues

the  Government’s  medium-term  strategy  and  which  address  cross-cutting  issues,  are  also

D. Lessons Learned
30. Formulating the Project has benefited from the experience and lessons learned from
many completed or ongoing projects assisted by the ADB,21 JBIC, and World Bank. A summary
of valuable lessons learned follows:
(i)  More  active  participation  of  traditional  rural  communities  in  the  mainstream
formal economy should begin with empowerment of the communities through
social  mobilization,  organization,  and  improved  access  to  adjoining  growth
centers where there is a market for the goods and services that the villages can
produce.
(ii)  Emphasis  on  developing  human  resources  at  the  local  level  is  the  key  to
community empowerment.
(iii)  The villages that receive block grants should have considerable control over the
details of how their grants are spent. The block grant system is demonstrably
successful  in  spurring  communities  to  prioritize  their  needs  and  to  allocate
available  resources  to  these  activities  reflecting  their  priorities  and  potential

accountable.
(v)  If the villages have to compete for infrastructure funds, the rules of competition
should favor small-scale labor-intensive projects that will provide facilities for use
by  the  local  communities.  Substantial  savings  are  made  using  village-based

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A.  Rationale
37. The Project is designed to address the significant shortcomings that have led to social
exclusion of the rural poor and a continuation of their capability deprivation. First, as local
communities become involved in the development planning and implementation process, a

12
major challenge concerns the lack of institutional capacity to effect planning and allocation of
resources for community development. The major constraints include the following:
(i)  Weak human resources at the community, subdistrict, and district levels of government
where  the  link  between  civil  society  and  government  needs  to  be  strong  to  utilize
resources  intended  for  rural  areas.  For  lack  of  resources  and  skills,  many  village
community leaders in the project areas are unable to effectively plan or communicate
their community development needs. Their primary spokespersons in the government
hierarchy, the DGRCE staff in the subdistrict, are spread too thin or lack the necessary
resources, skills, and incentives to serve their constituent villages adequately.
(ii)  Domination by sectoral agencies. In the subdistrict, major development priorities are
usually  set  by  sectoral  agencies,  often  with  little  or  no  consultation  with  local
communities.
(iii)  Insufficient  resource  allocation.  At  present,  the  allocation  (about  $1,250  per  year)
received by villages for planning development activities is inadequate for preparing more
than lists of items proposed by villagers for local rural infrastructure. Village participation
in effect would be no more than a few meetings conducted for that purpose. Under Law
25, the amount will likely increase with the increased budget allocations to elected
district governments. However, the villagers will need new mechanisms to ensure that
the  planning  process  goes  beyond  mere  listing  of  their  wishes,  and  measures  to
enhance  the  transparency  of  their  decision  making  and  accountability  for  using
resources.
38. Given these constraints, skilled human resources, and new institutions and mechanisms
supportive  of  community  development  and  anchored  in  grassroots  democracy  and  social
inclusion of the poor, will need to rapidly evolve to realize the good intentions of the new laws. A
focused effort and allocation of resources will be needed to encourage local government and
village communities to assume their new responsibilities. Toward this end, the Project will
support formal and informal training of local government staff and villagers, and a development
planning  process  aimed  at  improved  identification  of  and  resource  allocation  for  local
development needs. The process will be based on participatory approaches whereby villagers
themselves will have the opportunity to identify local problems and propose solutions, organize
themselves to implement those solutions, and monitor the results. The Project will thus lay the
groundwork for local government and communities to institute socially inclusive mechanisms
through which they can have a voice and choice in decision making concerning how public
resources will be used for their benefit. Past initiatives with similar objectives have failed for lack
of such local institutional capacity and mechanisms.
39. The second set of challenges revolves around significant but not intractable constraints
to rural economic growth opportunities for the poor in Kalimantan and Sulawesi, caused by the
exclusion  of  rural  communities  from  regional  growth  centers  (i.e.,  markets),  from  financial
services, and from information necessary to actually access those markets. For lack of capital,
many poor villagers who wish to engage in off-farm income-generation activities are unable to
do so. The feasibility study identified 48 types of microenterprises that villagers would like to
invest in if they had access to affordable credit. Through the development planning process to
be supported under the Project, communities will be encouraged to invest in microenterprises
and provided access to formal financial services after raising capital from their savings. Many
areas and village communities lack access roads and other rural infrastructure (e.g., bridges,
jetties, and markets) to establish commercial linkages to regional centers and benefit from
spillover effects of their growth. The Project will support construction of rural infrastructure that

13
will improve the commercial links between the target villages and the growth centers in the
project area.
B.  Objectives and Scope
1.  Objectives
40.  By addressing a range of social exclusion issues that lead to capability deprivation
among the poor, the Project aims to increase the real incomes of the poor, particularly the
poorer rural communities in the peripheral areas of regional growth centers. The objectives of
the Project are to (i) empower rural communities by strengthening their capacity to plan and
manage  their  own  development  activities  in  a  socially  inclusive  manner,  and  (ii)  support
investments  and  foster  rural  urban  linkages  by  establishing  rural  infrastructure  to  promote
agricultural productivity and off-farm business enterprises.
2.  Scope
41.  The Project will comprise four components:
a. Capacity Building for Decentralized Development Planning (Part A)
42. Part A seeks to empower communities and strengthen the capacity of village and local
officials under a decentralized framework. It will support capacity building for communities and
community institutions, local government workers (district, subdistrict, and village levels), and
national and provincial officials to develop new skills, that they will need to function effectively
under the new administrative and financial setup for the decentralized government system.
Empowerment will be achieved through the following subcomponents:
(i)  Institutional  development.  This  subcomponent  will  (a)  introduce  a  planning
process and related training and other institutional capacity-building activities to
encourage and help communities to develop and test community-based planning
mechanisms and to formulate and propose village development plans for funding
by  project  implementation  units  (PIUs);  (b)  establish  intervillage  community
development working groups (Kelompok Kerja Pembangunan Masyarakat) to
facilitate and advocate development proposals promoting linkage of neighboring
villages  that  require  PIU  funding  support; and  (c)  skills  training  for  local
government staff to enhance their capability to facilitate, monitor, and support
local community development initiatives.
(ii)  Human resources development. This subcomponent will support formal degree
training for 1,773 staff of DGRCE and local government dealing with community
development, including those at district and subdistrict levels, to form a nucleus
of skilled staff dealing with decentralized development planning. The proportion
of women trained will be at least 30 percent of the total for the diploma, 25
percent for the bachelor’s degree program, and 20 percent for the master’s
degree program. The domestic master’s degree program includes specialization
in  rural  development  planning,  rural  community  development,  and  public
administration, while the international master’s degree program includes social
planning and development, and development management. DGRCE will ensure
that  staff  who  have  participated  in  the  formal  domestic  and  foreign  degree
training programs will be assigned to a Project position relevant to the training,
for at least twice the length of the period of the training received. About 90

14
officials  will  conduct  a  short-term  comparative  study  of  decentralization,
community  and  village  planning,  CBSLO  formation,  and  microenterprise

(iii)  Provision  of  village  grants  to  support  the  community  training  program.  This

c.  Improvement of Rural Infrastructure (Part C)
44. Part  C  will  provide  needed  rural  infrastructure  in  the  project  area  to  link  poor
communities to markets in the urban centers. The rural infrastructure will increase access to
markets and services and reduce the disproportionately high transaction costs faced by poor

a. Provinces, Districts, Subdistricts, and Villages
 
46. The  four  project  components  will  be  fully  implemented  in  11  districts  in  six  core
provinces in eastern Indonesia: Central Kalimantan, East Kalimantan, and South Kalimantan,
and Central Sulawesi, North Sulawesi, and Southeast Sulawesi (map, page vi). However, part A

the  six  provinces.  During  this  period,  the  community-based  planning  mechanism  and  the

the  start  of  implementation,  the  geographic  coverage  of  part  A  may  be  extended  to  the

have been designated as expansion provinces, would benefit from the experience and lessons
learned in conducting village training in the six core provinces.
47. At project formulation which began in 1998, the assistance of the World Bank and JBIC
was concentrated on the islands of Java, Bali, and Sumatra, and was aimed at reducing poverty
by constructing or rehabilitating rural infrastructure in the rural areas, such as roads, and water
supply and sanitation facilities. To avoid duplication of efforts and overlaps, the Government and
ADB agreed that the proposed Project would focus its assistance on the outer islands of
Sulawesi and Kalimantan. In this manner, the Project would also support the Government’s
policy  of  promoting  balanced  regional  development  by  focusing  assistance  on  the  less
developed eastern region and reducing poverty. Because by 1998 the World Bank and JBIC
coverage had extended even to Sulawesi and Kalimantan, it was agreed that only subdistricts
that were not covered by the other aid agencies would be selected for the Project.
48. The rural infrastructure component of the Project follows the strategy of linking poor
villages to growth centers and growth corridors to access markets in these areas. Growth
centers are towns and cities where above-average growth has taken place in recent years.
Growth corridors comprise long sections of main roads linking subdistricts to growth centers and
along which some villages develop economic activities. Examples of growth corridors are the
main road connecting Banjarmasin to Kapuas and Barito, and the main road connecting Palu
and Poso. Using rapid rural appraisal and SUSENAS25 data, 72 subdistricts were selected on
the following criteria: (i) contain at least 1,500 households, (ii) contain IDT villages to reach the
largest number of poor people, (iii) possess potential linkage to regional growth centers and
growth corridors, (iv) have moderate year-round accessibility, and (v) avoid overlap by not
participating in the World Bank and JBIC rural infrastructure projects.
49. The following criteria will be used to target poor villages. To be eligible, a village will (i)
not  be  covered  by  ongoing  foreign-assisted  projects  involving  microfinance  or  rural
infrastructure during the project implementation period; (ii) be in a cluster of about 3-10 villages
and within a reasonable distance from a growth center; (iii) have an existing commercial link to
growth centers, including at least 10 percent of households with commercial activities selling
goods or services at such growth centers; and (iv) be in the bottom third of the participating
subdistrict in terms of proportion of poor. To select the villages, workshops will be conducted at
the subdistrict level involving PIU staff, NGOs, village chiefs, and community representatives
from village dusun (village subunits or settlements). Details of the overall strategy for targeting
the poor are described in paras. 88 and 89.

development  training,  and  village-level  planning  through  the  participatory  approach.
Communities are not homogeneous and to ensure the participation of women and men in the
village development planning process, groups will be formed in each dusun comprising people

c. Targeting Poor People
51. The Project will target poor households with annual income of less than Rp670,000
($100). The rapid rural appraisal conducted during the feasibility study have identified poor
households that can afford only two meals a day; whose members are landless, sharecroppers,
fisherfolks without boats; are headed by women; and are involved in subsistence farming, and
small  trading  and  selling  of  home-cooked  food  and  beverages.  A  survey  of  potential
beneficiaries in the six provinces indicated that at least two thirds of the population are very poor
and  poor.  On  the  two  islands,  the  typical  family  depends  on  subsistence  agriculture.  In
Kalimantan, the typical family has a bicycle to take produce to the market and to serve the
transport needs of the members. The house is made of wood with a wooden floor but is poorly
maintained. Many houses have a pressed earthen floor. Many families use firewood for cooking
and have access to a sealed well and pump for potable water, although the majority in the same
village have only open wells. In Sulawesi, the typical family also relies on subsistence farming,
but earns supplementary income from handicrafts made at home. The house is traditionally
raised above the ground and is made of timber. The house has wooden-slat windows. Firewood
is also used extensively for cooking, and a kerosene stove is for special occasions. There are
pumps in the village, but the family uses an open well for drinking water.
52. The following strategy will be used in targeting poor households:26 (i) villages with a
majority of poor people will be targeted; (ii); village development plans will explicitly identify the
needs and concerns of poor people; (iii) village planning committees will include at least two
representatives of the poor; (iv) to allow participation of poor people with low literacy, two thirds
of the trainees in the community training program to be designed will be from poor households;
(v) two thirds of the total borrowers from the CBSLOs will be from poor households; (vi) no
minimum savings levels will be established in opening a CBSLO savings account to avoid
excluding the poor; (vii) CBSLO lending terms and repayment period will be set at sufficiently
low levels to allow poor borrowers to gain experience in using credit (the CBSLO will set the
level and repayment period as an explicit part of the membership guidelines to encourage the
participation of the poor); (viii) proposals for rural infrastructure projects under part C will include
an explanation of the benefit for the poor; and (ix) poverty impact indicators are included in the
baseline surveys and in the MIS under the Project to provide data for monitoring and targeting
the participation of the poor in project activities.

D.  Financing Plan
55. Considering  Indonesia’s  economic  difficulties  and  fiscal  constraints  in  the  short  to
medium term, the Government requested that, as an interim measure, ADB’s share in project
financing  be  increased  to  80  percent  of  the  project  cost.  Although  Indonesia’s  economic
recovery is continuing, the economic situation remains difficult. Public debt has ballooned to
about 93 percent of gross domestic product, excluding the Government’s contingent liabilities.
Consequently, the Government’s debt service burden has risen sharply. Given the anticipated
tightness in the fiscal situation, the Government expressed its difficulty, at least in the short run,
in providing 40 percent share of the cost in project financing from its budgetary sources. The
World Bank currently provides 75 percent of project costs on a three-year rolling average and a
further  increase  in  its  share  is  understood  to  be  under  World  Bank’s  consideration.  JBIC
currently provides about 85 percent of project costs. Under these circumstances, it is proposed
that ADB’s share of the project cost be increased to 80 percent for the first three years of project
implementation and revert to 60 percent after the third year. The temporary relaxation of ADB’s
cost-sharing limit for project financing is being sought as a purely temporary measure to assist
Indonesia tide over its fiscal difficulties and to support Indonesia’s incipient economic recovery.
A similar financing arrangement is being proposed for all project loans for Indonesia to be
considered by the Board in 2000. This proposal is in accordance with the graduation policy,
which  allows  ADB  financing  to  exceed  the  country  cost-sharing  limit  under  exceptional
circumstances and where justified on country and project grounds (para. 86). 27
56. It is proposed that ADB provide two loans comprising  (i) the loan in various currencies

$65 million equivalent from its ordinary capital resources (OCR), with interest to be determined
in accordance with the ADB pool-based variable lending rate system for US dollar loans, with a
maturity of 25 years, including a grace period of 6 years, a front-end fee of 1 percent of the OCR
loan amount, and an annual commitment charge of 0.75 percent. The proposed ADB loans

2.  Social Analysis
85. The Project is to be implemented in six provinces in various agroecological zones: from
settled agriculture in North Sulawesi to upland and sometimes swidden cultivation in Central
Sulawesi, mixed tree-crop farming in Southeast Sulawesi, and lowland river-based agriculture
and aquaculture in South Kalimantan. This implies a large range of settlement patterns and
production techniques.  The areas range from the mono-ethnic groups in North Sulawesi to the
complex but established Christian and Muslim communities in Central Sulawesi, coastal Malays
and riverine Dayaks in Kalimantan, a mix of old communities and new settlements in Southeast
Sulawesi, a receiving area of the overflow from the historically disaster-prone South Sulawesi.34
Thus, the project area is diverse in the nature of resources to be developed and in terms of
peoples, what they do, and how they do it.
86.  The districts have been selected because they are poor, and relatively isolated by virtue
of distance, difficult geography, and poor infrastructure.  As a result of this isolation they have
relatively limited access to information about a range of subjects, from production technologies
to prices.  In marketing they tend to be price takers, dependent on either the village trader or a
few  itinerant  buyers.  They  have  also  been  relatively  underserved  by  government  and
development  projects  and  in  terms  of  basic  education  and  health  services.  Under
decentralization, their future access to basic services and development will depend on how well
they are able to articulate their needs and priorities to local government. The new situation will
be a significant departure from their experience to date, which has been largely as recipients of
assistance that, from a local perspective, occurred at unpredictable times and of a type and
quantity only loosely linked to local needs and conditions. Significant capacity building will be
required to link these populations, not only economically but politically, to their local leaders and
decisions makers.

of girls and boys in basic education has increased. In some districts, Banjar in South Kalimantan

be keeping women at home. At the same time, the proportion of women seeking work in North

aspects of the Project directly related to the preparation or undertaking of economic activities in
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of Projects. All investments in parts B
and C, 60 percent of total investments in part D, and all investments in part A related to

100. The Project will benefit both economic and social development by ensuring that the
targeted districts, villages, and individuals have the benefit of improved local administrative
capability,  support  for  participatory  planning  and  implementation  of  improvements  in  rural
infrastructure,  and  access  to  financial  services  and  microenterprise  support.  The  poor  in
particular  will  benefit  from  much  improved  economic  opportunities  grounded  in  the
empowerment of rural village communities.
B. Environment
101. Since  the  IEE  assessed  two  categories  of  project  activities  (civil  works  and
entrepreneurial  activities)  could  have  potential  environmental  impact,  an  environmental
management and monitoring plan will be prepared. The services of an environmental specialist
will be engaged at the start of project implementation to prepare the plan. Private sector
contractors, the PIU, and village staff involved in the construction of civil works under part C,
and CBSLO and BPD officials involved in the processing and approval of subborrower loans for
entrepreneurial activities under part B will actively participate in managing and monitoring the
environment. This will ensure that any potential environmental impact is minimized and project
activities fully conform to the environmental guidelines of the Government and ADB.
C. Social Dimensions
102. The Project is designed to link underserved villages commercially to growth centers and
to institute a process whereby all villagers, including the poor, are able to plan village-level
development and form self-help savings and loan organizations. In this regard, the Project has
several important social features. It targets IDT villages: almost all the 72 subdistricts to be
covered by the  Project have a preponderance of IDT villages, which is the best available proxy
at the design stage to locate the Project in poor rural areas in the six provinces. Based on
information  obtained  during  the  feasibility  study  and  a  sample  of  village  socioeconomic
profiles,36 it is estimated that over half of the 750 villages to be covered are IDT villages. Most
households in these villages are at or below the poverty line, estimated at Rp670,000 (less than
$100) per annum in year 2000 values. Interviews conducted during the TA feasibility studies
period and during the Loan Fact-Finding and Appraisal Missions confirmed that many, if not the
majority, of project participants would be those at or below the poverty line.

33
103. To ensure that more reliable and poverty-sensitive criteria are used and to provide an
opportunity for the DGRCE field staff and for potential target beneficiaries to participate in the
selection process, it was decided not to finalize village selection during the project design stage.
Rather, the villages would be selected in year 1 of project implementation, following a rapid rural
appraisal of each subdistrict and consultation (using focus group interview techniques) with a
sample of potential beneficiaries.
104. The Project will make a significant investment in process-oriented activities to involve a
broad  spectrum  of  local  government  and  village  participants  in  identifying,  preparing,  and
implementing  village  development  plans  and  in  forming  and  operating  the  CBSLOs.  Such
activities will account for about 20 percent of the total project cost. The investment is expected
to  generate  significant  positive,  although  intangible,  social  impacts:  inclusion  of  target
beneficiaries alongside local government officials in making key decisions concerning the use of
funds for local development at the level where they matter most. This feature will ensure that
Project-funded  activities  will  be  demand-driven  and  “owned”  by  local  communities,  thus
underscoring  the  purpose  of  the  decentralization  laws.  More  specifically,  through  the
community-based  planning  mechanisms,  Kelompok Kerja Pembangunan Masyarakat  and
CBSLOs, village participants would develop and apply planning and management skills for local
development. It is expected that these villagers, if not themselves poor people, would also be in
a position to advocate and address the interests of the poor and any disadvantaged groups in
the village institutional context as well as within the new local government framework. The
Project would thus empower the targeted rural communities by providing them the capabilities to
put social meaning into the government decentralization process.
1. Gender Considerations
105. Reconnaissance studies and other information gathered during the feasibility studies
indicate  that  women  and  particularly  relatively  poor  women  form  the  majority  of  micro-
entrepreneurs and savers in rural communities in the six provinces. Women from several ethnic
groups in Sulawesi have established a strong tradition in producing and selling in local markets
handicrafts such as mats, stone jewelry (with distinctive designs of their ethnic groups), and
processed foods from their home gardens. This observation is mirrored in the list of proposals
obtained from feedback interviews with potential target beneficiaries – the majority involved food
or product processing and small businesses commonly operated by women. These findings
provide  assurance  that  women  will  benefit  directly  from  the  Project’s  investments  in
microenterprise development, provided care is taken that this assumption is borne out during
project implementation, and that poor women are not outcompeted by better-off members of the
CBSLOs in seeking loan support. Training for CBSLOs will emphasize inclusion of women in all
aspects of operations. Lending policies will be tailored to the demand of women entrepreneurs
and skewed in favor of poor women. The project consultants will work out the details during
implementation of the CBSLOs formation subcomponent.
2. Indigenous People’s Plan
106. An  indigenous  people’s  plan  was  prepared.  The  Mission  assessed  the  Project  as
essentially neutral for indigenous people. It will not have a negative effect on their cultural or
political norms or affect their access to land or other resources. The empowerment process
under part A will be beneficial to marginal communities that wish to participate and which may
have been neglected in the previous centrally planned development process. Local communities
will be given greater opportunities and increased skills to plan, manage, and decide on the
content and direction of their own development plans. Part of the subdistrict development plan
will be identifying and mapping marginal or isolated communities and groups. In general, the

34
Project is expected to bring positive benefits to indigenous people by giving them access to
mainstream services and to improved governance practices (Appendix 15).
D.  Impact on Poverty
1.  Poverty Reduction
107. The Project targets the poor by helping them secure their livelihood through improved
microfinance services and rural infrastructure, empowering them in village economic and social
life through village-level social mobilization, and influencing the political process by increasing
the capacity of local officials to respond to the needs of the poor. The Project promotes the
participation of women at every step of this process and brings microfinance services to the
village,  enabling  women  to  save  and  obtain  credit  more  securely,  and  thus  reduce  their
dependence on moneylenders. The Project will also benefit about 4,500 community leaders
trained in participatory approaches, management skills, and financial management.
108. The Project aims to reduce poverty by increasing the incomes of about 425,000 people,
or 85,000 families, through microenterprise and small enterprise development. Of these, about
370,000 people, or 74,000 families, are expected to move above the poverty line. The Project
will directly benefit about 550,000 people, or 110,000 families, in the project area, equivalent to
4 percent of the population, through capacity building for local government, employment, and
enterprise development. About 1.1 million people, or 220,000 families, in 750 villages in 11
districts will benefit from improved rural infrastructure enabling them access to markets in
nearby urban centers or growth corridors for their products and to social and health services. An
estimated 185,000 jobs will be generated from project activities. The Project will extend the
geographic scope of its community training and community empowerment, under part A, to an
additional 40 districts from 20 expansion provinces following successful midterm evaluation of
the Project. The community-based planning mechanism introduced are key to instituting good
governance practices in the community development process.
2. Nonquantifiable Benefits
109. The  Project  addresses  social  exclusion  issues  that  when  resolved,  will  bring  non-
quantifiable benefits to the rural communities and the poor. The community-based planning
mechanisms to be introduced under part A will involve democratic practices and processes to
anchor decision making over what and how resources would be used for communal benefit.
Participants will be elected by villagers and proposals for the village development plans will be
considered and approved by elected representatives (village-level and community-level), in an
intervillage forum. These mechanisms are key to instituting good governance practices in the
community development process. In that respect, the Project will help effect the democratic
underpinnings of decentralized government as promulgated by the two decentralization laws.
The  trainees  will  include  government  officials  in  the  subdistricts  and  districts  where  these
processes  currently  are  weakest.  The  Project  is  envisaged  to  strengthen  the  village
communities’ ability to articulate and lobby for support for their development plans as well as
their respective district governments’ ability to respond to their demands. As the Project will
target poor villages, this capacity-building process will directly benefit the poor by providing
them a means to draw the attention of local government and resources to their development
needs.  Furthermore,  the  Project  criteria  that  women  be  adequately  represented  in  the
institutions  and  training  activities  to  be  sponsored  will  mean  that  women  as  well  as  men
participate in and benefit from the process.

35
110. Increased  opportunities  for  diploma  and  degree  training  under  the  human  resource
development subcomponent will widen the base of trained local government workers. About
1,634 staff in subdistricts and districts will be trained for a three-year diploma or a four-year
bachelor’s  degree  under  the  Project.  This  should  improve  their  capability  for  community
development work, with subsequent positive impacts on their morale and productivity. For
another 139 senior officials who would receive postgraduate training locally and overseas, the
opportunity to attend universities will widen their experience and provide new insights into how
development planning is carried out in Indonesia and in the region. It will also allow them to
learn from the experiences of others.
111. The formation of community members into CBSLOs, together with associated training
and support, will empower them by ensuring their representation and participation in sustainable
village development and resource management activities. Membership in the CBSLOs will also
(i) improve access of the participants to financial services for livelihood or supplemental income-
generating activities; (ii) strengthen their income-earning capacities; and (iii) equip them with the
necessary skills in small enterprise management and entrepreneurship in a wider variety of
occupations, thus widening their financial options. The heightened awareness of women of their
important role in the success of project initiatives, the enhancement of their skills for livelihood
development  activities  and  credit  and  savings  mobilization,  and  their  empowerment  for
community leadership and resource management activities are anticipated to be important
project achievements. Similarly, for both men and women, improvement in confidence and
morale with direct participation in both planning and implementing village plans and the Project
can produce lasting change.
112. The provision of basic social infrastructure facilities (e.g., potable water supply, drainage,
and community halls) will improve the general health of the community residents as a result of
better  personal  hygiene  and  sanitation.  Most  of  all,  investments  in  rural  roads  will  open
opportunities for poor people in villages to market their produce at better prices and to access
products and services. Probably no other single form of investment creates the same level of
nonquantifiable benefits as small rural roads connecting villages to the major transport and
communication systems.
E.  Risks
113. If implemented as planned, decentralization of administrative and financial functions is
expected to improve project implementation in line with the envisaged improvement in the
efficiency  of  delivery  of  public  services.  In  addition,  the  Project  will  assist  in  the  general
democratization process through the capacity-building program under part A of the Project,
which is the essential adjunct to decentralization. Increasing participation by ordinary (including
poor) people in the decision-making process and the corresponding pressure from them for
transparency will greatly assist in combating the dangers from malfeasance and corruption.
114. The prevailing ambiguity about the precise nature of the division of administrative and
financial  responsibilities  between  different  levels  of  government  for  implementing  rural
development programs poses two types of risk in project implementation. First, would the
Central Government leave the entire counterpart financial responsibility for implementing the
Project on the participating province or districts? Second, given the ensuing changes in the
system of fiscal transfers from the Central to the regional governments, including the channeling
of external assistance, would the participating provinces and districts be expected to shoulder
the financial burden of servicing and repaying the ADB loans for the Project? The Government
has  provided  assurances  that  limit  the  uncertainties  in  the  financial  and  institutional
arrangements for project implementation that may arise from the division of administrative and

36
financial responsibilities between different levels of government. The Government assured the
ADB Appraisal Mission that such changes are internal to the Government and that the Central
Government  as  the  Borrower  would  remain  responsible  for  the  counterpart  financial
commitment to the Project.
115. As with most projects, the timely availability of counterpart funds will be necessary for
success as well as the availability of counterpart personnel at national, provincial, and district
levels.  The  Government’s  continued  commitment  to  improving  the  capacity  of  regional
governments  and  to  poverty  reduction  should  ensure  that  the  necessary  resources  are
forthcoming. The Government has agreed that annual budgets will be provided to the Project
through special allocations to ensure timeliness of funds needed for implementation, and an
expanded formal education program will widen the base of trained local workers at subdistrict
and district levels, thus addressing the concerns about availability and quality of counterpart
staff.
116. Within  the  Project  itself,  there  will  always  be  risks  associated  with  investment  in
microenterprises even though their finances appear reasonably robust. Much also will depend
on the organization and capacity of the CBSLOs and especially on the commitment of CBSLO
members. For this reason, the Project has provided for NGO facilitators, most of whom will be
drawn from NGOs in the area concerned, including existing credit unions where available, to
provide  in-depth  contact  and  discussion  encouraging  prospective  beneficiaries  to  actively
participate in CBSLO formation. The Mission at appraisal had assessed that suitable NGOs and
NGO facilitators are available in the project area.
117. The  financial  and  economic  risks  associated  with  microenterprise  development  are
inevitably present, but the financial and economic analyses indicate a reasonable degree of
robustness.

SIX REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT BANKS
A.  Introduction
1. To  support  the  development  of  community-based  savings  and  loan  organizations
(CBSLOs) in the project area, six regional development banks (Bank Pembangunan Daerah or
BPD) will serve as Executing Banks. CBSLOs will be formed in each participating village to
mobilize savings, provide financial services among the members, and manage small loans for
enterprise development. The six BPDs are BPD Central Kalimantan, BPD East Kalimantan,
BPD South Kalimantan, BPD Central Sulawesi, BPD North Sulawesi, and BPD Southeast
Sulawesi.
2. The BPDs are owned by the provincial and local governments. They were established in
1961-1965  to  promote  regional  development,  increase  regional  income  sources,  and  help
develop rural financial institutions. In 1967, an act allowed the BPDs to accept demand deposit,
grant short-term loans, and participate in equity investments, thereby expanding their powers
and enabling them to compete with regular commercial banks. The BPDs have headquarters in
the  provincial  capital,  and  branches  in  the  districts.  Not  all  BPDs  have  branches  in  the
subdistrict. BPD South Kalimantan has a strong background in microfinance gained from the
ADB’s Microfinance Project; the five other BPDs have been involved in Government-funded
microfinance schemes.
B.  Performance of the Six BPDs
1.  Financial Indicators
3. The assets of the six BPDs increased by 15.8 percent annually during the last five years.
Their combined total assets amounted to Rp1,582.4 billion ($226 million equivalent) at the end
of 1999. The growth in assets is attributed to the BPDs’ profitable operation as well as to
additional capital infusion to one BPD from the owners.
4. In terms of profitability, all six BPD performed well during the past five years, except for
BPD North Sulawesi, which barely made a profit and did not meet the acceptable return on
equity (ROE) for three years. As a result, BPD North Sulawesi was recapitalized and underwent
major structural changes in 1999. Its profitability slightly improved by the end of 1999 when it
posted a 9 percent ROE. The total assets, total equity, and net income after tax of the six BPDs
from 1995 to 1999 are in Table A6.1.
5. Combined  with  the  growth  in  assets,  the  six  BPDs  have  increased  their  interbank
placements and reduced their loans receivable. On the average, the six BPDs loan portfolio is
only 34 percent of their total productive assets. A substantial portion of their productive assets is
in interbank placements rather than in loans receivable. Interbank placements are temporary
investments and are also a liquidity buffer. Because of the financial crisis in 1997, it was
relatively safer to put money in other banks than to extend loans. However, the demand for
loans  is  expected  to  increase  and  so  the  loan  portfolio  is  also  expected  to  grow,  as  the
Indonesian  economy  recovers  from  the  shock  of  1997  and  interest  rates  continue  on  a
downtrend. Table A6.2 shows the distribution of the productive assets of the six BPDs by the
end of 1999.
6. In terms of growth, the combined loan portfolio of the six BPDs increased in 1996 and
1997, but contracted by 3.9 percent in 1998, compared with the 1995 level. Only BPD South
Kalimantan and BPD Southeast Sulawesi were able to significantly increase their loan portfolio.
All six BPDs were affected by the financial crisis and experienced collection problems. During
the crisis, lending activities slowed down but lending showed signs of picking up in 1999. Table
A6.3 shows the loan portfolio of six BPDs during the last five years.

3.  Improving BPD Central Sulawesi Operations
14. The Mission assessed the effect of the nonperforming loans on the future operations of

4. Effect of Proposed Relending by MOF to Six BPDs
15. The respective capital1 of all the six BPDs will remain adequate even after disbursement
of the entire $2.5 million MOF credit loan to each BPD. Among the six BPDs, BPD Central
Sulawesi has the smallest capital at Rp9.8 billion ($1.4 million). Its capital adequacy ratio, which
stood at 38 percent at the end of 1999, would have increased to 41 percent by year 2001
without the MOF credit loan. With the $2.5 million loan, its capital adequacy ratio can still be
maintained within the 34-38 percent level, which is considered more than sufficient. Its loan-to-
deposit ratio will increase from 43 percent to 104 percent, which is within acceptable standards,
after it has onlent the funds to the project CBSLOs.
D. Bank Indonesia’s Assessment of the Six BPDs
16. Bank  Indonesia  assessment  of  the  six  BPDs  in  March  2000  indicates  that  all  are
financially sound. However, BPD Central Sulawesi received a rating of “less than satisfactory”
mainly because of its high ratio of nonperforming loans. This BPD continues to operate normally
and accept deposits from the public.
17. The  Mission  was  informed  that,  considering  the  above  rating,  Bank  Indonesia  had
conducted a “fit and proper test” of senior officers and operational procedures of BPD Central
Sulawesi. The result of the test gave BPD Central Sulawesi a passing mark. Bank Indonesia
and BPD Central Sulawesi have agreed on measures to reduce the amount of nonperforming
loans in one year to improve the BPD’s Bank Indonesia classification.
E.  Financial Projections for BPDs
18. The Mission examined the future financial viability of the six BPDs based on CAMEL
rating for 2001–2006. The assumptions used common to all the BPDs are summarized in Table
A6.8. The BPDs were assumed to maintain a cash balance equivalent to 1 month operating
expenses plus 5 percent of demand liabilities. Excess funds were assumed to be placed in other
banks as call loans or plain deposits.
19. Based on historical data for each BPD as well as in the aggregate, the Mission projected
the growth rates of the loan portfolio as well as the demand liabilities of the BPDs. BPD Central
Sulawesi was able to increase its loan portfolio by 36.3 percent in 1996, but posted negative
growth rates in 1997 and 1998 due to the Asian financial crisis. It posted a 3 percent growth rate
in 1999. Assuming economic recovery in Central Sulawesi Province, the BPD may be capable
of  duplicating  the  36  percent  growth  rate  of  its  loan  portfolio  in  1996.  However,  using
conservative projections, the Mission assumed a gradual increase of 10 percent in 2000, 15
percent in 2001, 20 percent in 2002, and increases of 2 percent thereafter.

A.  Introduction
1. The  financial  analysis  focused  on  the  financial  viability  of  the  possible  representative

microenterprises under the Project. As it is difficult to quantify the benefits from the capacity

taken as a whole. The analysis was based on the economic benefits derived from representative
microenterprises and investment costs on village-level training, consulting services for community
development, domestic technicians, community-based savings and loan organization (CBSLO)
formation, rural infrastructure improvement, rural infrastructure operation and maintenance, and
project  management.  Costs  in  the  economic  analysis  included  physical  contingencies,  but

expressed in the domestic price numeraire.
B.  Financial Analysis
1. Representative Microenterprises
2. Twelve microenterprise models were identified and chosen as representative of possible
livelihood projects that CBSLO members may engage in. The representative microenterprises
included: (i) agricultural activities (chicken, vegetable, and cocoa production); (ii) food processing
(pineapple candy, palm sugar, and kerupuk [crackers]); (iii) handicraft making (furniture, handbag,
and palm leaf thatching); and (iv) service enterprises (welding shops, stores and restaurants, and
transportation services) (Table A14.1). These microenterprises require minimal capital investments
and are easy to implement, given the limited skills, types of resources available, and low level of
education  of  prospective  investors.  The  financial  analysis  covered  six  years,  comprising  an
establishment period of one year and an operation period of five years. The financial assessment
consisted of the following calculations: (i) investment cost, (ii) working capital requirement, (iii)
annual operating cost, (iv) profit and loss forecast, and (v) cash flow for financial planning.  The
benefit-cost ratio (BCR) for each microenterprise was estimated to determine their viability.
3. The analysis indicated that each of the representative microenterprises was financially
sound and had a calculated BCR greater than one. A summary of the investment and financial
models for the microenterprises is in para. 95 of the RRP. Return to labor is calculated by dividing

increases in production costs (14-36 percent), compared with other types of investment activities to

INDIGENOUS PEOPLE PLAN
1. For the purposes of the Project's Indigenous People Plan, indigenous people are those who
meet the Government definition of "isolated communities." Under Ministerial Decree 5/1994, isolated
communities are described as groups of people who live or wander in dispersed, isolated areas and
follow a sociocultural system which is "isolated" and "left behind" in comparison with the rest of
Indonesian society. "Isolated" is understood in terms of both geography and culture, while "left
behind" is understood in terms of such measures as health, education, housing, clothing, and
livelihood. Some characteristics of isolated communities, according to the National Development
Planning Agency (BAPPENAS) are as follows:  (i) a nomadic or seminomadic lifestyle, or living in
small, dispersed bands; (ii) livelihood system strongly dependent on the natural environment, such
as hunting, gathering, fishing, or swidden agriculture; (iii) inadequate standards of personal hygiene
or cleanliness of environment; (iv) meager or no clothing; (v) low standard of housing;  (vi) very
limited knowledge and low use of technology; (vii) belief system that is animistic; and (viii) strong
attachment to their cultural and belief systems, which makes them culturally closed.
2. These communities or groups also have in common many of the following traits relevant to
the concept of indigenous people:  "Priority in time with respect to the occupation and use of a
specific  territory.  The  voluntary  perpetuation  of  cultural  distinctiveness,  which  may  include  the
aspects of language, social organization, religion and spiritual values, modes of production, laws and
institutions. Self Identification as well as recognition by other groups, or by the State authorities, as a
distinct collective group; and an experience of subjugation, dispossession, marginalization, exclusion
or discrimination, whether or not these conditions persist."
3.  The Ministry of Social Affairs is responsible for the development of communities that have
been  classified  as  “isolated  communities,”  through  the  Directorate  General  of  Social  Welfare
Development under the Directorate for Isolated Communities. Implementation of isolated community
development programs under the directorate includes settlement in place of origin, resettlement, and
coordination and cooperation of technical agencies to facilitate their accessing and mainstreaming
into general development activities.  While indigenous people cannot be identified on the basis of an
official list of "Isolated Communities," nor enumerated by reference to official census records, agency
records can be used to identify districts where indigenous people are likely to be located.  The

had isolated community development in the past, and which are therefore considered to potentially
